habitat_description:
This species is presumed extirpated in California (Hayes and Pearl 2005) although an account exists within the California Wildlife Habitat Relationship System. I coded the range as historic for HUCs in California.

The Oregon spotted frog was listed as threatened by the USFWS in 2013. It has been eliminated from between 70% and 90% of its former range in the Pacific Northwest where it previously occupied suitable habitats from southern British Columbia to northern California (Hayes and Pearl 2005). An almost entirely aquatic species of perennial waterbodies with abundant emergent or floating plants, this ranid is particularly susceptible to predation and competition by non-native species such as the bullfrog. They occupy warm emergent marshes/wetlands >4ha in size and elevations up to 5450 feet (1661 meters)(Nussbaum et al. 1983, Hayes, 1994, Hayes 1997).  Oregon spotted frogs breed in warm, vegetated shallows of open, freshwater marshes and lake margins with little flow (Licht, 1971). Breeding micro-environments are often located in seasonally inundated shallows, and are usually hydrologically connected to permanent water (Licht, 1971). Individuals move among seasonal habitats usually along flooded or saturated corridors (Watson et al. 2003)(Hayes and Pearl 2005). From NatureServe write-up:
"In central Oregon, breeding habitats were natural or anthropogenic and ranged from small, seasonally flooded oxbow ponds to larger channels and marshes within an extensive wetland complex; most sites had extensive emergent and submergent vegetation (Bowerman and Pearl 2010). Wintering sites are in springs, slow-flowing channels, or deep open water (Hallock and Pearson 2001, Chelgren et al. 2008). Pearl and Hayes (2004) reviewed available literature and summarized habitat relationships as follows. Oregon spotted frogs are generally associated with wetland complexes > 4 ha in size with extensive emergent marsh coverage that warms substantially during seasons when the frogs are active at the surface. The expanse of inundation in wetlands often varies greatly between spring and fall, but sites always include some permanent water adjacent to seasonally inundated habitat. Field observations and recent telemetry data suggest the frog utilize different wetland microhabitats for breeding, the nonbreeding active season (summer and portions of spring and fall), and overwintering."

In California, this species used to occupy low, swampy areas in mountainous woodlands and wet meadows, stream edges and lakes of Shasta and Modoc counties at elevations ranging from 1000m to 1450m (Jennings and Hayes 1994, Wright and Wright 1949, Dumas 1966, Stebbins 1985).
